articles.headline: Ahead of I.P.O., Twitter Alters Feed to Add Images
articles.snippet: The change could increase user numbers, and also help the company sell more visual ads.
articles.abstract: The change could increase user numbers, and also help the company sell more visual ads.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter has gone visual.

articles.headline: Ackman Sees Expansion of Activist Investing to Europe
articles.snippet: In a speech at the University of Oxford, William A. Ackman also spoke about his investments in J.C. Penney and his bet against Herbalife.
articles.abstract: In a speech at the University of Oxford, William A. Ackman also spoke about his investments in J.C. Penney and his bet against Herbalife.

articles.headline: 100 Years Down the Line
articles.snippet: Automakers like Ford are finding that building multiple models on an updated, ever-evolving line is integral to success in the global marketplace.
articles.abstract: Automakers like Ford are finding that building multiple models on an updated, ever-evolving line is integral to success in the global marketplace.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — THE moving assembly line was the simplest of inventions, born of necessity to meet the exploding demand for automobiles in America in the early 20th century.

articles.headline: Hail to the Minivan, Dowdy but Not Out
articles.snippet: Although surging sales for the minivan are a distant memory — Americans bought 1.37 million in 2000 — the vehicle has found its niche.
articles.abstract: Although surging sales for the minivan are a distant memory — Americans bought 1.37 million in 2000 — the vehicle has found its niche.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE minivan was a cliché almost from the moment the first Dodge Caravan rolled off Chrysler’s assembly line in 1983. It was the boxy family hauler aimed at harried soccer moms, a symbol of the soul-crushing conformity that was the price Americans paid for suburban comfort.

articles.headline: Chocolate Factory, Trade War Victim
articles.snippet: A power struggle between the European Union and the Russian-backed Customs Union is squeezing Roshen, the largest confectioner in Ukraine.
articles.abstract: A power struggle between the European Union and the Russian-backed Customs Union is squeezing Roshen, the largest confectioner in Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — From the Baltic to the Black Sea, a chocolate wall has descended across the continent of Europe.

articles.headline: New Chief of the F.C.C. Is Confirmed
articles.snippet: The Senate voted unanimously to confirm President Obama’s two picks for the Federal Communications Commission, Tom Wheeler as chairman and Michael O’Rielly as a commissioner.
articles.abstract: The Senate voted unanimously to confirm President Obama’s two picks for the Federal Communications Commission, Tom Wheeler as chairman and Michael O’Rielly as a commissioner.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted unanimously on Tuesday to confirm President Obama’s two nominations to the Federal Communications Commission, overcoming obstacles by Republican lawmakers.

articles.headline: In Race for Boston Mayor, Former Addicts Back Candidate With a Past
articles.snippet: Martin J. Walsh is a recovering alcoholic, and his campaign has moved many former addicts to step out from the shadows and publicly support him.
articles.abstract: Martin J. Walsh is a recovering alcoholic, and his campaign has moved many former addicts to step out from the shadows and publicly support him.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Tom White, who says he used to swig two six-packs of beer while driving home from work, has been sober for 25 years. Now, his Toyota Corolla has a vanity plate that reads “ONEDAY,” a reference to the Alcoholics Anonymous slogan “one day at a time.” On the rear windshield is a sticker for Martin J. Walsh, a candidate for mayor of Boston.

articles.headline: Lighter and Faster, It’s iPad Air
articles.snippet: The improvements on the new tablet are incremental, not revolutionary, but Apple still holds the edge compared with the other tablets on the market.
articles.abstract: The improvements on the new tablet are incremental, not revolutionary, but Apple still holds the edge compared with the other tablets on the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The iPad Air is noticeably lighter than its predecessors.

articles.headline: Where the Buck Stops, Some See a Bystander
articles.snippet: President Obama has been under fire for his seeming detachment from significant matters, like the rollout of the health insurance website and secret spying on allied heads of state.
articles.abstract: President Obama has been under fire for his seeming detachment from significant matters, like the rollout of the health insurance website and secret spying on allied heads of state.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama finds himself under fire on two disparate fronts these days, both for the botched rollout of his signature health care program and for the secret spying on allied heads of state. In both instances, his explanation roughly boils down to this: I didn’t know.

articles.headline: Spying Known at Top Levels, Officials Say
articles.snippet: The White House has long been aware in general terms of the National Security Agency’s overseas eavesdropping, the nation’s top spymaster told a House hearing on Tuesday.
articles.abstract: The White House has long been aware in general terms of the National Security Agency’s overseas eavesdropping, the nation’s top spymaster told a House hearing on Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s top spymaster said on Tuesday that the White House had long been aware in general terms of the National Security Agency’s overseas eavesdropping, stoutly defending the agency’s intelligence-gathering methods and suggesting possible divisions within the Obama administration.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Ousted General in Egypt Is Back, as Islamists’ Foe
articles.snippet: Gen. Mohamed Farid el-Tohamy’s swift and silent rehabilitation from corruption charges, critics say, signals a restoration of the old order after the military takeover.
articles.abstract: Gen. Mohamed Farid el-Tohamy’s swift and silent rehabilitation from corruption charges, critics say, signals a restoration of the old order after the military takeover.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A year after the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak, the man responsible for rooting out government corruption, Gen. Mohamed Farid el-Tohamy, faced a very public barrage of allegations that he had deliberately covered up years of cronyism and self-dealing.
